abstract.para: Add-on products are system extensions. They can either be free extensions based on &productname; (such as , or additional products requiring a registration key that is liable to costs (such as the &sle; &hasi;, for example). They can either be available on physical media or as repositories only that are available for you after registering your system at &scc; or a local registration server.
Some add-on products are also provided by third parties, for example, binary-only drivers that are needed by certain hardware to function properly.

If you have such hardware, refer to the release notes for more information about availability of binary drivers for your system. The release notes are available from , from &yast; or from /usr/share/doc/release-notes/ in your installed system.

sect1.title: &sdk; (SDK) &productnumber;
sect1.para: &sdk; &productnumber; is an add-on for &sle; &productnumber;. It is a complete tool kit for application development. In fact, to provide a comprehensive build system, &sdk; &productnumber; includes all the open source tools that were used to build the &sls; product. It provides you - as a developer, independent software vendor (ISV), or independent hardware vendor (IHV) - with all the tools needed to port applications to all the platforms supported by &sled; and &sls;.

&sdk; also contains integrated development environments (IDEs), debuggers, code editors, and other related tools. It supports most major programming languages, including C, C++, Java, and most scripting languages. For your convenience, &sdk; includes multiple Perl packages that are not included in &sle;.
For detailed information, refer to . Use the &yast; add-on installer and package manager to install &sdk; &productnumber;.

sect1.title: Installing Add-Ons and Extensions
sect1.para: A list of available add-on products and extensions is available after having registered your system at &scc; or a local registration server. If you skipped the registration step during the installation, you can register your system at any time using the &scc; Configuration module in &yast;.

note.title: Available Extensions and Modules
note.para: The amount of available extensions and modules depends on the registration server. A local registration server may only offer update repositories and no additional extensions at all.

tip.title: &sled;
tip.para: As of &sle; 12, &sled; is not only available as a separate product, but also as an extension for &sls;. If you register at the &scc;, the &sled; extension can be selected for installation. Note that installing it requires a valid registration key.

procedure.title: Registering Your System and Installing Extensions

step.para: Start &yast; and select Support &scc; Configuration to open the Registration dialog.

Provide the E-mail address associated with the &suse; account you or your organization uses to manage subscriptions. In case you do not have a SUSE account yet, go to the &scc; home page ( to create one.
Enter the Registration Code you received with your copy of &productname;.

Proceed with Next to start the registration process. If one or more local registration servers are available on your network, you will be able to choose one of them from a list. Alternatively, choose Cancel to ignore the local registration servers and register with the default &suse; registration server.
During the registration the online update channels will be added to your installation setup.
After successful registration, &yast; shows a list of extensions, add-ons, and modules that are available for your system.
Click an entry to see its description. Select one or multiple entries for installation by activating their check marks.
Click Next to proceed.
The respective repositories from the registration server will be added to your system—no additional installation sources are required.

sect1.para: To open the &yast; Add-On Products module, start &yast; and select Software Add-On Products . Alternatively, start it from the command line with sudo yast2 add-on.

procedure.para: When installing an add-on, you can select various types of product media, like CD, FTP, USB mass storage devices (such as USB flash drives or disks) or a local directory. You can work also directly with ISO files. To add an add-on as ISO file media, select Local ISO Image then enter the Path to ISO Image. The Repository Name is arbitrary.
To install a new add-on, proceed as follows:

step.para: In &yast; select Software Add-On Products to see an overview of already installed add-on products.
To install a new add-on product, click Add.
From the list of available Media Types specify the type matching your repository.
To add a repository from a removable medium, choose the relevant option and insert the medium or connect the USB device to the machine, respectively.
You can choose to Download Repository Description Files now. If the option is deactivated, &yast; will automatically download the files later, if needed. Click Next to proceed.
When adding a repository from the network, enter the data you are prompted for. Continue with Next.
Depending on the repository you have added, you may be asked if you want to import the &gpg; key with which it is signed or asked to agree to a license.
After confirming these messages, &yast; will download and parse the metadata. It will add the repository to the list of Configured Repositories.
If needed, adjust the repository Properties as described in .
Confirm your changes with OK to close the configuration dialog.
After having successfully added the repository for the add-on media, the software manager starts and you can install packages. Refer to for details.
